history.content: This would need an instructor response since I am not sure whether or not this has changed, but if it's the same as last year, the waitlist is processed when adjustment begins (assuming there are no constraining factors i.e. 70% rule), and any majors that were already on the waitlist prior to the end of Phase 2 are given priority. Any majors that added themselves to the waitlist during the adjustment period were not given priority over non-majors that were already on the waitlist at that point.
Check out the CS enrollment policy page and the EE enrollment policy page!

children.subject:
I don't think this accurately answers the student's question (if it does, this policy is a little weird):

"3. In Phase II, all declared LSCS and EECS majors will be enrolled starting from the beginning of the existing waitlist. Any UC student can put themselves on the waitlist

4. Once Phase II is over (i.e. mid-August and mid-January for Fall and Spring semesters; also see the Schedule), during open enrollment, any UC student will be enrolled starting from the beginning of the existing waitlist. Neither major status nor class standing will impact enrollment at this point."

I would assume that if a sophomore CS major signs up for a course during Phase 2 but is waitlisted due to the 70% rule, that they would have enrollment priority off the waitlist above a senior non-CS major who was able to get on the waitlist earlier due to an earlier CalCentral Phase 2 appointment. Theoretically, that sophomore CS major would have been able to enroll ahead of the senior non-major had the 70% rule not been instituted and ends up getting the short end of the stick because of the above policy.

Please clarify whether or not this is the case or if the above policy needs to be revised.
Nothing about the policy implies that enrollment priority overrides the 70% rule.

@Steven, no what I am saying is that a declared major student who should have priority during Phase 2 but is forced to waitlist like other students ends up losing priority when the waitlist is processed (assuming there is no separate waitlist for majors). It makes sense that the 70% rule is implied regardless of enrollment priority, but a senior non-major with an earlier Phase 2 gets spot x on the waitlist while a sophomore major gets spot x + y on the waitlist, and thus when the waitlist is processed the sophomore major is behind the senior non-major, even though both students signed up for the course during Phase 2. If there is a separate waitlist for majors or if majors who signed up pre-adjustment period are processed first, this is not an issue.

There is a single waitlist. There is no "processing first" other than the regular enrollment priorities.

If the class opens its seats during Phase 2 when there are enrollment restrictions, then the sophomore major will get into the class first.

If the class opens its seats during the adjustment period when there aren't enrollment restrictions, then the senior non-major will get into the class first.

That's what I'm saying doesn't make sense to me. Let's say today is the last day of Phase 2. If the waitlist begins processing today, the sophomore CS major gets priority. But if it opens tomorrow the sophomore CS major loses priority. This seems arbitrary and unfair to me. I understand that majors lose priority if they try to enroll during the adjustment period. But if a CS major signs up for a course during Phase 2, they should have priority enrolling off the waitlist regardless of when the processing starts since they signed up for that class during Phase 2 when they were supposed to have priority.

So as a declared CS major, I think I will be put on the WL for a certain upper div (it looks like it will be full before my phase 2). The current waitlist has over 150 students which are theoretically all non majors. If I end up being put on the WL in phase 2, will I get priority over all those people who have been waitlisted?

history.content: When will CS/EECS department begin filling available spots in upper divs with those in the waitlist? Is it when adjustment begins (August 14th), or when classes begin? Also, when this process begins, are waitlists processed in a first-come-first-served basis, or will majors be given priorities even then?
history.subject: Waitlist Process for Non-Majors
